instruction: [INST] Analyze this file to learn MacBook motherboard repair. The 'definitions' section explains key technical terms. The 'threads' section contains real-world repair discussions. Use both sections to understand and learn how to troubleshoot MacBook issues. Posts from username 'larossmann' , 'dukefawks' , and '2informaticos' are posts from trusted experts.[/INST]

definitions.820-3023: What is 820-3023? a LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER.
definitions.PPBUS_G3H: What is PPBUS_G3H? Main system power rail that charges the battery, or is power from the battery, that everything else is powered from. .
definitions.ISL6259: What is ISL6259? This is a charging chip for Macbook motherboards from 2010 through 2015.
definitions.SMC_RESET: What is SMC_RESET? SMC_RESET is not a signal, it is an abbreviation for “SMC_RESET_L”, which is the signal someone is referring to when they type “SMC_RESET”  "SMC_RESET_L is a signal that resets the SMC when it is low(this is what the “_L” prefix means), and lets the SMC out of reset mode when it is high. .
definitions.SMBUS_SMC_BSA_SDA: What is SMBUS_SMC_BSA_SDA? SMBUS_SMC_BSA_SDA is the clock line of an I2C data line between the battery charging chip that creates PPBUS_G3H, the system management controller(SMC), the battery, and the battery indicator LED..
definitions.SMBUS_SMC_BSA_SCL: What is SMBUS_SMC_BSA_SCL? SMBUS_SMC_BSA_SCL is another way to say SMBUS_SMC_5_G3_SCL, look at the definition provided for SMBUS_SMC_5_G3_SCL as it applies to .

threads.title: Macbook air <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-3023</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>-A no green light
threads.message:
When I plug the power cable there are curent on ppbus g3h and the 3v42 was also here. but the green light not be there ?
I change the <CHIP>U6900</CHIP> but no change. The 3v42 (3v39 in real) was on the <CHIP>U6900</CHIP> but the green light don't turn on . Why ??
please to help me :-)

threads.title: Macbook air <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-3023</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>-A no green light
threads.message: What is  the voltage on <SIGNAL>PPBUS_G3H</SIGNAL>??? Also check for corrosion on I/O board or flex....

threads.title: Macbook air <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-3023</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>-A no green light
threads.message: Known good IO board and flat cable are also a good place to start. But PPBUS voltage can tell a lot too.

threads.title: Macbook air <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-3023</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>-A no green light
Macbook air <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-3023</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>-A no green light
threads.message: SMC is not running, check if <SIGNAL>SMC_RESET</SIGNAL> L is present, if yes, check diode mode on <SIGNAL>SMBUS_SMC_BSA_SCL</SIGNAL> and <SIGNAL>SMBUS_SMC_BSA_SDA</SIGNAL>, this could be a bad <CHIP>ISL6259</CHIP> or a bad SMC...

threads.title: Macbook air <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-3023</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>-A no green light
threads.message:
I found 0.67v for <SIGNAL>SMC_RESET</SIGNAL> L
and diode mode 0.79v on <SIGNAL>SMBUS_SMC_BSA_SCL</SIGNAL> and <SIGNAL>SMBUS_SMC_BSA_SDA</SIGNAL>

threads.title: Macbook air <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-3023</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>-A no green light
Macbook air <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-3023</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>-A no green light
threads.message: Those readings are all sorts of weird. Pin 8 is a simple regulator output and should be 3V, pin 6 should also be high. Are you sure this is correct? Seems like <CHIP>U5100</CHIP> could be dead or corroded trace to pin 1 or 3.

threads.title: Macbook air <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-3023</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>-A no green light
threads.message:
Ok i changed the <CHIP>U5010</CHIP> and now it boot :-)
thanks ! ;-)
BUT now the power button don’t works. All keys are working. So I think the button not is the real problem. I used a ssd from a mbp so perhaps it is that because the mbp have is button not on the keyboard ????

threads.title: Macbook air <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-3023</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>-A no green light
threads.message: Firstly connect a known good separate keyboard to rule that out.

threads.title: Macbook air <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-3023</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>-A no green light
threads.message: I have no other MacBook Air on the hand

threads.title: Macbook air <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-3023</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>-A no green light
threads.message: All keyboard have the same pinout. You can even use a separate keyboard from a macbook pro. Any macbook keyboard will be ok for testing.

threads.title: Macbook air <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-3023</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>-A no green light
threads.message: I have used the touch’s on the circuit for the power on and it doesn’t work ! So it is not the keyboard ?

threads.title: Macbook air <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-3023</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>-A no green light
threads.message:
I have used the touch’s on the circuit for the power on and it doesn’t work

I have no idea what you mean.

threads.title: Macbook air <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-3023</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>-A no green light
threads.message:
sorry I am French
I have shorted the power-on pads and it don't boot

threads.title: Macbook air <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-3023</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>-A no green light
threads.message: Check continuity from power on pads to <RESISTOR>R5070</RESISTOR>. If OK then remove <CHIP>U5010</CHIP> and do a diode mode reading on the power on pads.
